paragraph: "Whatever's up down there?"

paragraph: "Why, what a question!  Do you suppose a match between Guinea-pigs and Tadpoles _ever_ came to an end?  They had a free fight at the end of the first innings. paragraph: By this time they had reached the door of the Fourth Junior room, whence proceeded a noise such as one often hears in a certain popular department of the Zoological Gardens.  Amid the tumult and hubbub the two friends had not much difficulty in slipping in unobserved and seating themselves comfortably in an obscure corner of the festive apartment, behind a pyramid of piled-up chairs and forms.
tokens: time reach door fourth room proceed noise such hear certain popular department zoological tumult hubbub friend have much difficulty slip unobserved seating obscure corner festive apartment pyramid pile chair form

paragraph: The Junior "cricket feast" was an institution in Saint Dominic's, and was an occasion when any one who had nerves to be excruciated or ear-drums to be broken took care to keep out of the way.  In place of the usual desks and forms, a long table ran down the room, round which some fifty or sixty urchins sat, regaling themselves with what was left of a vast spread of plum-cake, buns, and ginger-beer.  How these banquets were provided was always a mystery to outsiders.  Some said a levy of threepence a head was made; others, that every boy was bound in honour to contribute something eatable to the feast; and others averred that every boy had to bring his own bag and bottle, and no more.  Be that as it might, the Guinea-pigs and Tadpoles at present assembled looked uncommonly tight about the jackets after it all, and not one had the appearance of actual starvation written on his lineaments.
tokens: cricket feast institution occasion one have nerve excruciated ear drum break take care keep way place usual desk form long table run room urchin sit regale leave vast spread plum cake bun ginger beer banquet provide mystery outsider say levy threepence head make other boy bind honour contribute eatable feast other averr boy have bring own bag bottle more guinea pig tadpole present assemble look tight jacket have appearance actual starvation write lineament

paragraph: The animal part of the feast, however, was now over, and the intellectual was beginning.  The tremendous noise which had brought Oliver and Wraysford on to the scene had indeed been but the applause which followed the chairman's opening song--a musical effort which was imperatively encored by a large and enthusiastic audience.
tokens: animal part feast intellectual begin tremendous noise bring scene applause follow chairman open song musical effort encore large enthusiastic audience

paragraph: The chairman, by the way, was no other than our friend Bramble, who by reason of seniority--he had been two years in the Fourth Junior, and showed no signs of rising higher all his life--claimed to preside on all such occasions.  He sat up at the top end in stately glory, higher than the rest by the thickness of a Liddell and Scott, which was placed on his chair to lift him up to the required elevation, blushingly receiving the applause with which his song was greeted, and modestly volunteering to sing it again if the fellows liked.
tokens: chairman way other friend reason seniority year fourth show sign rise high life claim preside such occasion sit top end stately glory high rest thickness place chair lift require elevation receive applause song greet volunteering sing fellow like

paragraph: The fellows did like.  Mr Bramble mounted once more on to the seat of his chair, and saying, "Look-out for the chorus!" began one of the time-honoured Dominican cricket songs.  It consisted of about twelve verses altogether, but three will be quite enough for the reader.
tokens: fellow like mount seat chair say look chorus begin time honoure dominican cricket song consist verse enough reader

paragraph: "There was a little lad,   (Well bowled!)   And a little bat he had;   (Well bowled!)   He skipped up to the wicket,   And thought he'd play some cricket,   But he didn't, for he was--   Well bowled!

paragraph: "He thought he'd make a score   (So bold),   And lead-off with a four   (So bold);   So he walked out to a twister,   But somehow sort of missed her,   And she bailed him, for he was   Too bold.

paragraph: "Now all ye little boys   (So bold),   Who like to make a noise   (So bold),   Take warning by young Walker,   Keep your bat down to a yorker,   Or, don't you see? you'll be--   Well bowled!"

paragraph: The virtue of the pathetic ballad was in the chorus, which was usually not sung, but spoken, and so presented a noble opportunity for variety of tone and expression, which was greedily seized upon by the riotous young gentlemen into whose mouths it was entrusted.  By the time the sad adventures of Master Walker had been rehearsed in all their twelve verses, the meeting was so hoarse that to the two elder boys it seemed as if the proceedings must necessarily come abruptly to a close for want of voice.
tokens: virtue pathetic ballad chorus sung speak present noble opportunity variety tone expression seize riotous young gentleman mouth entrust time sad adventure rehears verse meeting hoarse elder boy seem proceedings come close want voice

paragraph: But no!  If the meeting was for the moment incapable of song, speech was yet possible and behold there arose Master Paul in his place to propose a toast.
tokens: meeting moment incapable song speech possible behold arise place propose toast

paragraph: Now Master Paul was a Guinea-pig, and accounted a mighty man in his tribe.  Any one might have supposed that the purpose for which he had now risen was to propose in complimentary terms the health of his gallant opponents the Tadpoles.  This, however, was far from his intention.  His modesty had another theme.  "Ladies and gentlemen," he began.  There were no ladies present, but that didn't matter. Tremendous cheers greeted this opening.  "You all know me; I am one of yourselves."  Paul had borrowed this expression from the speech of a Radical orator, which had appeared recently in the papers.  Every one knew it was borrowed, for he had asked about twenty of his friends during the last week whether that wouldn't be "a showy lead-off for his cricket feast jaw?"
tokens: guinea pig account mighty man tribe one suppose purpose rise propose complimentary term health gallant opponent intention modesty have theme lady gentleman begin be lady present matter tremendous cheer greet opening know borrow expression speech radical orator appear paper one know borrow ask friend last week showy lead cricket feast jaw

paragraph: The quotation was, however, now greeted as vociferously as if it had been strictly original, and shouts of "So you are!"
tokens: quotation greet original shout

paragraph: "Bravo, Paul!" for a while drowned the orator's voice.  When silence was restored his eloquence took a new and unexpected departure.  "Jemmy Welch, I'll punch your head when we get outside, see if I don't!"  Jemmy Welch was a Guinea-pig who had just made a particularly good shot at the speaker's nose with a piece of plum-cake.  "Now, ladies and gentlemen, I shall not detain you with a speech (loud cheers from all, and `Jolly good job!' from Bramble).  I shall go on speaking just as long as I choose, Bramble, so now!  (Cheers.)  I've as much right to speak as you have.  (Applause.)  You're only a stuck-up duffer.  (Terrific cheers, and a fight down at the end of the table.)  I beg to drink the health of the Guinea-pigs.  (Loud Guinea-pig cheers.)  We licked the old Tadpoles in the match.  (`No you didn't!'  `That's a cram!' and groans from the Tadpoles.)  I say we did!  Your umpire was a cheat--they always are!  We beat you hollow, didn't we, Stee Greenfield?"
tokens: while drown orator voice silence restore eloquence take new unexpected departure punch head get see guinea pig make good shot speaker nose piece plum cake lady gentleman detain speech loud cheer good job go speak choose cheer have much right speak have applause stuck duffer terrific cheer fight end table beg drink health guinea pig loud pig cheer lick old match cram groan say umpire cheat beat

paragraph: "Yes, rather!" shouted Stephen, snatching a piece of cake away from a Tadpole and shying it to a Guinea-pig.

paragraph: "That's eight matches we've won," proceeded Paul; "and--all right, Spicer!  I saw you do it this time!  See if I don't pay you for it!" whereat the speaker hurriedly quitted his seat and, amid howls and yells, proceeded to "pay out" Spicer.
tokens: match win proceed right see do time see pay speaker quit seat howl yell proceed pay

paragraph: Meanwhile Stephen heard his name suddenly called upon for a song, an invitation he promptly obeyed.  But as the clamour was at the time deafening, and the attention of the audience was wholly monopolised by the commercial transactions taking place between Paul and Spicer, the effect of the performance was somewhat lost.  Oliver certainly did see his young brother mount up on the table, turn very red in the face, open his mouth and shut it, smile in one part, look sorrowful in another, and wave his hand above his head in another.  But that was the only intimation he had of a musical performance proceeding.  Words and tune were utterly inaudible by any one except the singer himself--even if _he_ heard them.
tokens: hear name call song invitation obey clamour time deafen attention audience monopolise commercial transaction take place effect performance lose see young brother mount table turn red face open mouth shut smile part look sorrowful wave hand head only intimation have musical performance proceed word tune inaudible one singer hear

paragraph: This was getting monotonous, and the two visitors were thinking of withdrawing, when the door suddenly opened, and a dead silence prevailed.  The new-comer was the dirtiest and most ferocious-looking of all the boys in the lower school, who rushed into the room breathless, and in what would have been a white heat had his face been clean enough to show it.  "What do you think?" he gasped, catching hold of the back of a chair for support; "Tony Pembury's kept me all this while brushing his clothes!  I told him it was cricket feast, but he didn't care!  What do you think of that?  Of course, you've finished all the grub; I knew you would!"
tokens: get monotonous visitor think withdraw door open dead silence prevail new comer dirtiest ferocious look boy low school rush room breathless white heat have face clean show think gasp catching hold back chair support keep brush clothes tell cricket feast care think course finish grub know

paragraph: This last plaintive wail of disappointment was drowned in the clamour of execration which greeted the boy's announcement.  Lesser feuds were instantly forgotten in presence of this great insult.  The most sacred traditions of Guinea-pigs and Tadpoles were being trampled upon by the tyrants of the upper school!  Not even on cricket feast night was a fag to be let off fagging!
tokens: last plaintive wail disappointment drown clamour execration greet boy announcement lesser feud forget presence great insult sacred tradition pig tadpole trample tyrant upper school cricket feast night fag let fagg

paragraph: It was enough!  The last straw breaks the camel's back, and the young Dominicans had now reached the point of desperation.

paragraph: Oliver went to the door; it was shut.  He pushed; it was fortified.  He kicked on it; a defiant howl greeted him from the inside.  He called aloud on his fag; another "Shan't come!" was his only answer.

paragraph: The same answer was given, accompanied with the same yell, and Oliver's temper went faster than ever.  He forgot he was making himself ridiculous; he forgot he was only affording a triumph to those whom he desired to punish; he forgot the good resolutions which had held him back on a former occasion, and, giving way to sudden rage, kicked desperately at the door once more.

paragraph: This time his forcible appeal had some effect.  The lower panel of the door gave way before the blow and crashed inwards, leaving a breach large enough to admit a football.

paragraph: It was an unlucky piece of success for Oliver, for next moment he felt his foot grabbed by half a dozen small hands within and held firmly, rendering him unable to stir from his ridiculous position.  In vain he struggled and raged; he was a tight prisoner, at the mercy of his captors.
tokens: unlucky piece success next moment feel foot grab small hand hold rendering unable stir ridiculous position vain struggle rage tight prisoner mercy captor

paragraph: It was all he could do to stand on his one foot, clinging wildly to the handle of the door.  In this dignified attitude Wraysford presently found his friend, and in such a state of passion and fury as he had never before seen him.
tokens: do stand foot cling handle door dignified attitude find friend state passion fury see

paragraph: To rap the array of inky knuckles inside with a ruler, and so disengage the captive foot, was the work of a minute.  Oliver stood for a moment facing the door and trembling with anger, but Wraysford, taking him gently by the arm, said, "Come along, old boy!"
tokens: rap array inky knuckle ruler disengage captive foot work minute stand moment face door tremble anger take arm say come old boy

paragraph: There was something in his voice and look which brought a sudden flush into the pale face of the angry Oliver.  Without a word, he turned from the door and accompanied his friend back to the study.  There were no long talks, no lectures, no remorseful confessions that evening.  The two talked perhaps less than usual, and when they did it was about ordinary school topics.
tokens: be voice look bring sudden flush pale face angry word turn door accompany friend study be long talk lecture remorseful confession evening talk less usual do ordinary school topic

paragraph: No reference was made either then or for a long while afterwards to the events of the evening.  And yet Oliver and Wraysford, somehow, seemed more than ever drawn together, and to understand one another better after this than had ever been the case before.
tokens: reference make long while event evening seem more draw understand good case
